Graphical abstract Zeolite-encapsulated ruthenium(III) salophen (ZERS) was prepared by flexible ligand method and characterized by diffuse reflectance FT-IR and UV–vis spectroscopic methods, X-ray diffraction, BET, SEM, TEM and elemental analysis. The amount of Ru-salophen in the zeolite supercages was 0.018mmol/g of encapsulated zeolite. This catalyst was used for efficient and selective epoxidation of different alkenes with NaIO4 under magnetic stirring and ultrasonic irradiation conditions. This catalyst also showed a good shape-selectivity in the epoxidation of linear alkenes. This heterogeneous catalyst was reused several times without significant loss of its catalytic activity. Keywords Ruthenium salophen Zeolite Y Sodium periodate Epoxidation Reusable catalyst 1 Introduction Transition metal complexes have been extensively used for homogeneous oxidation of organic substrates [1–3]. However, the recovery and recycling of these catalysts are difficult because of degradation of the organic ligands, and dimerization of the transition metal complexes. In comparison with the homogeneous catalysts, heterogeneous systems present many advantages such as easy separation and recovery of the catalyst from reaction media, higher stability of the catalytic species and catalyst protection against destruction [4]. There are several strategies for heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts such as polymerization of homogeneous catalysts, immobilization of homogeneous catalysts via covalent bonding either directly (grafting) or through a spacer ligand (tethering), and finally physical entrapment of metallocomplexes into nanopores and nanocages of inert supports bearing suitable pore sizes and well-defined structure such as zeolites. These supporting methods enhance the stability and reactivity of homogeneous catalysts [5–8]. Among them, the latest method has gained considerable attention in comparison with conventional heterogeneous catalysts due to the negligible leaching of metal ions [8–10]. Encapsulation is one of the most often used methods for homogeneous catalysts immobilization, and is an effective way to mimic the homogeneous catalysis. This method does not change the chemical properties of the immobilized catalyst except for the steric confinement of porous supports [11]. Encapsulation of transition metal complexes in the nanopores of molecular sieves mainly depends on the sizes of both complex and pores of the support. The matching of these two sites is very important to prevent the leaching of immobilized catalysts during the reaction. Zeolites are a class of excellent candidates for the encapsulation of homogeneous catalysts [12–17]. Upon encapsulation in nanocage of zeolites, complexes may lose some of their degrees of freedom and accept exclusive geometry which may differ from homogeneous counterparts and therefore, special characteristics such as size/shape-selectivity can be attained [1,4,18,19]. There are three major approaches for encapsulation of metallocomplexes into the nanocages of zeolite (ship-in-a-bottle): (i) flexible ligand method [4,10,20,21], (ii) template synthesis method [22–24], and (iii) zeolite synthesis method [25,26]. In the flexible ligand method, the ligand can easily diffuse through the nanocavities of the zeolite due to sufficient flexibility but upon the complexation with metal ion, becomes too large and rigid to pass through the zeolite channels and therefore entrapped in the cages of zeolite [4,20]. In the last two decades, Schiff base ligands have received more attention, mainly because of their extensive applications in the fields of synthesis and catalysis [27–34]. In order to increase the catalyst stability, their complexes (salen or salophen) have been immobilized on different supports and their catalytic activity has been investigated in organic synthesis [35–49]. In continuation of our previous works on the encapsulation of catalysts in the supercages of zeolites [9,24,25], here, we report the preparation, physico-chemical characterization and application of zeolite-encapsulated [Ru(salophen)Cl] (ZERS) in the epoxidation of alkenes with NaIO4 under magnetic stirring and ultrasonic irradiation conditions (Scheme 1 ). 2 Experimental All solvents and reagents were commercial grade and purchased from Merck, Fluka and Aldrich. Alkenes were passed through a column containing active alumina to remove the peroxidic impurities. The NaY zeolite was obtained from Sigma–Aldrich chemical company. 2.1 Instrumental All reactions under magnetic stirring were carried out at room temperature in a 25ml glass reactor. Reactions under ultrasonic irradiation were carried out in a 20ml glass reactor. Sonication was carried out by a UP 400S ultrasonic processor with 24kHz frequency equipped with a 3mm wide and 140mm long probe, which was immersed directly into the reaction mixture. The total volume of the solution was 10ml. The temperature reached to 40°C during sonication. Gas chromatography analyses (GC) were carried out on a Shimadzu GC-16A instrument using a 2m column packed with silicon DC-200 or Carbowax 20m. In these analyses, n-decane was used as internal standard. X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on an Advanced Bruker D8 diffractometer using Cu-Kα radiation and a graphite monochromatic with scan speed 16°/min. The diffuse reflectance FT-IR and FT-IR spectra were recorded in the range 400–4000cm−1 by a Jasco 6300 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Scanning electron micrographs (SEM) of catalyst and parent zeolite were recorded on a Philips XL30 microscope. Transmission electron micrograph (TEM) was recorded on a Zeiss CEM 902A microscope. Specific surface area measurements were performed on a Quantachrome NOVA 2200 apparatus with nitrogen as the adsorption gas at 77K. The solid state UV–vis spectra were recorded by a Shimadzu UV-265 instrument using optical grade BaSO4 as reference. The salophen ligand was prepared according to the literature [50]. 2.2 Synthesis and purification of zeolite-encapsulated [Ru(salophen)Cl] 2.2.1 Preparation of Ru-exchange zeolite, RuY In a typical procedure, to a solution of ruthenium(III) chloride (0.915g, 7mmol) in deionized water (200ml) was added NaY zeolite (5g) and stirred at 313K for 24h. After then, the zeolite was filtered, washed thoroughly with distilled water and dried at 373K overnight. 2.2.2 Preparation of zeolite-encapsulated Ru(III) salophen (ZERS) ZRES catalyst was synthesized by “flexible ligand method”. In a typical procedure, RuY (1g) and H2 salophen ligand (3g) were mixed and heated under vacuum in an oil bath at 413–418K for 24h. The ligand was melted and reacted with metal to form the metal complex. After cooling, the solid was purified by Soxhlet extraction with ethanol for removal of metal complex on the surface, and dried at 353K. The purified sample was treated with 0.01M NaCl for 5h to remove the uncomplexed metal ions from the zeolite lattice. Finally, the catalyst was filtered and washed with hot water. The colored powder dried at 423K for 6h (Scheme 2 ). 2.3 General procedure for oxidation reactions catalyzed by ZERS under MS or US irradiation A solution of NaIO4 (1mmol) in H2O (2.5ml) was added to a mixture of alkene (0.5mmol), ZERS (600mg, 0.01mmol) in CH3CN (5ml). The reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature or exposed to US irradiation. The progress of the reaction was monitored by GC. After completion of the reaction, the catalyst was filtered and thoroughly washed with Et2O (20ml). The filtrates were purified on a silica-gel plate or a silica-gel column. The identity of the products was confirmed by IR and 1H NMR spectral data. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of zeolite-encapsulated ruthenium salophen (ZERS) The synthesis of zeolite-encapsulated ruthenium(III) salophen (ZERS) was carried out by flexible ligand method [9]. In this method, ligand is a flexible spice, but upon the complexation with metal ion, it becomes too rigid and large to exit from the nanocavity of zeolite. The crude material was treated with Soxhelt extraction with ethanol to remove the excess ligand and surface adsorbed complexes. The remaining uncomplexed metal ions were removed from the zeolite by re-exchanging with aqueous 0.01M NaCl solution. Upon formation of ruthenium(III) salophen cations into zeolite cages, the originally white zeolite turns to green. The color of the obtained material unchanged after the purification with Soxhlet extraction which confirmed the incorporation of ruthenium(III) salophen into NaY zeolite [10]. The ruthenium content of the catalyst was determined by XRF and ICP methods. The XRD pattern of the catalyst indicated that the ZERS has crystallinity almost identical to that of the parent NaY zeolite except with a slight change in the intensity of the peaks (Fig. 1 ). This fact proved that the framework and crystallinity of the zeolite remained unchanged upon encapsulation of ruthenium(III) salophen into the supercages of zeolite, and confirmed that the catalyst has been distributed in the zeolite. Reflections in regions of (220), (311) and (331) are related to the location of cations. Upon the encapsulation of ruthenium(III) salophen in the cages of zeolite, the order of relative peak intensities changes from (331)>(220)>(311) to (331)>(311)>(220) which confirms that by substitution of the Ru3+ ions at the location of Na+ ions, a rearrangement occurs during the complexation [51]. The FT-IR spectra of NaY zeolite, RuY zeolite and ZERS are shown in Fig. 2 . In these spectra, the bands in the range 450–1200cm−1 are attributed to the strong zeolite lattice vibration and bands in 3200–3600cm−1 are due to lattice water molecules and surface hydroxylic groups. The FT-IR bands of Ru(salophen) are weak due to its low concentration and were overlapped by the framework vibrations of the zeolite matrix. In the FT-IR spectra of ZERS, the bands at 500–1000cm−1 (out-of-plane bending vibration of aromatic ring), 1462 (CC bond stretching) are good indication for formation of Ru(salophen) in the zeolite cages. The stretching vibration of CN bond in the salophen ligand is masked by the band at 1631cm−1 (attributed to water vibration bands) [52]. Further information about the formation of metallocomplex and non-metallated material was obtained by diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectra of salophen-NaY zeolite and ZERS (Fig. 3A and B). The DR FT-IR spectrum of the non-metallated material exhibits the characteristic band of the CN (sym.) group at 1609cm−1. This band is shifted to lower frequencies by 20cm−1 in the FT-IR spectrum of ZERS due to the coordination of the imine nitrogens. The bands at 1495 and 1489cm−1 are attributed to CN (asym.) stretching vibration in the salophen-NaY zeolite and ZERS, respectively. In both compounds, the bands below 1000cm−1 are assigned to out-of-plane bending vibration of the aromatic rings. These bands are not observed in the DR FT-IR spectra of RuY zeolite and NaY zeolite (Fig. 3C and D). These observations indicated the presence of Ru(salophen) in the zeolite cavities. The UV–vis spectra of Salophen-NaY zeolite, Ru(salophen)Cl and ZERS were recorded in the range of 300–600nm. In this region, the salophen ligand showed a sharp peak and a shoulder at 338 and 390nm, respectively (Fig. 4A). In the Ru(salophen)Cl these two absorption peaks were also appeared at 338 and 390nm which was attributed to π–π* and n–π* transitions (Fig. 4B). The same peaks present in the UV–vis spectra of ZERS (Fig. 4C). This confirmed the formation of metallocomplex within the zeolite cages [4,53]. The scanning electron micrograph (SEM) of the NaY zeolite is identical to that of ZERS which confirmed that metallocomplex has been formed inside the nanocavity of zeolite not on the external surface (Fig. 5 ). The transmission electron micrograph (TEM) of ZERS is shown in Fig. 6 . The appearance of dark dots in the TEM image is an evidence for the formation of metallocomplex into supercages of zeolite. Surface area, pore volume, unit cell formula, unit cell dimension, analytical data and Si/Al ratio of NaY, RuY and ZERS are given in Table 1 . The content of Ru(salophen) in the synthesized sample, measured based on the Ru content of the ZERS by XRF and ICP methods, was obtained 0.018mmol/g of the supported catalyst. Decreasing the surface area and pore volume for RuY in comparison with the parent zeolite indicated that the small cations (Na) have been replaced with large cations (Ru). Insertion of Ru(salophen) considerably reduces the surface area and the pore volume of the zeolite which confirmed the formation of metallocomplex in the zeolite cavities and not on the external surface. Elemental analysis and XRF data proved that 3 complexes are present per 40 supercages in the unit cell (7.5% of supercages have been occupied by ruthenium complex). On the other hand, some ruthenium ions remained unreacted. These free cations are not able to catalyze the epoxidation reactions. The unit cell dimensions of ZERS are as same as the parent zeolite which shows that the zeolite structure remains unchanged during the formation of Ru(salophen) inside the cavities. 3.2 Effect of solvent on the epoxidation reactions In order to choose the reaction media, the effect of different solvents on epoxidation of cyclooctene was investigated. Among the mixture of acetonitrile, methanol, ethanol, acetone, dichloromethane, chloroform and ethyl acetate with water, the 2:1 mixture of acetonitrile/water was chosen as the reaction media due to the higher epoxidation yield. In the other solvents, the yield of reaction is very negligible. Acetonitrile can uniform the different phases and therefore, raise the mass transportation and increase the reaction yields (Table 2 ). 3.3 Effect of catalyst amount on the epoxidation of cyclooctene with NaIO4 In order to choose the optimum amount of catalyst, the epoxidation of cyclooctene (0.5mmol) with sodium periodate (1mmol) was performed in the presence of different amounts of ZERS catalyst. The best result was observed in the presence of 600mg (0.01mmol) catalyst. The results are shown in Table 3 . It is noteworthy that in the presence of RuY zeolite, only 23% of cycloctene oxide was detected under the same reaction conditions. This means that the catalytic activity of ZERS is due to the presence of Ru(salophen) in the zeolite cages and when the Ru coordinates to the salophen ligand a good catalytic activity is obtained. 3.4 Epoxidation of alkenes with NaIO4 in the presence ZERS under magnetic stirring Epoxidation of alkenes with sodium periodate in the presence of ZERS under magnetic stirring gave the corresponding epoxides in aqueous acetonitrile at room temperature (Table 4 ). In this catalytic system, cyclopentene, cyclohexene, cyclooctene, α-pinene, styrene and indene were completely oxidized. Except for styrene and α-pinene, in all cases the epoxides were obtained with 100% selectivity. Epoxidation of styrene was produced styrene oxide in 75% yield and 25% benzaldehyde was also detected. In the epoxidation of α-pinene, the yield of epoxide was 48%, and verbenol (22%) and verbenone (30%) were produced as by-products (Table 4). 3.5 Epoxidation of alkenes with NaIO4 in the presence of zeolite-encapsulated ruthenium-salophen (ZERS) under ultrasonic irradiation The most successful applications of ultrasound have been found in the field of heterogeneous chemistry involving solids and metals. This is due to the mechanical impact of ultrasound on solid surfaces. In conventional chemistry there are several problems associated with reactions involving solids or metals: small surface area of the solid/metal may limit reactivity, penetration of reactants into deeper areas is not possible, oxide layers or impurities can cover the surface, reactants/products have to diffuse onto and from the surface and reaction products can act as deposit on the surface and prevent further reactions. The mechanical effects of ultrasound offer an opportunity to overcome the following types of problem associated with conventional solid/metal reactions: breakup of the surface structure allows penetration of reactants and/or release of materials from surface, degradation of large solid particles due to shear forces induced by shock waves and microstreaming leads to reduction of particle size and increase of surface area and accelerated motion of suspended particles leads to better mass transfer [54]. Therefore, epoxidation of alkenes with NaIO4 in the presence of ZERS under ultrasonic irradiation was also investigated and the corresponding epoxides were obtained in excellent yield in aqueous acetonitrile. Under ultrasonic irradiation, the reaction times reduced and the yield of reactions enhanced that related to breaking-up the agglomerates and increasing the penetration of substrate to the zeolite cavities [25]. On the other hand, ultrasonic irradiation (US) can also be used to influence the selectivity and yield of reactions. A good example of increasing the selectivity under US irradiation was observed in the epoxidation of α-pinene in which 90% α-pinene oxide and 4% verbenol and 6% verbenone were produced (Table 5 ). In order to investigate the effect of ultrasonic irradiation, the size of catalysts were determined by particle size distribution technique before and after sonication. The results showed that the ultrasonic waves break-up the agglomerates. It seems that a part of ultrasonic irradiation effect is due to this phenomenon. On the other hand, ultrasonic irradiation increases the penetration of substrate to the zeolite cavities, and this lead to shorter reaction times as well as to higher product yields. 3.6 Shape-selectivity in the epoxidation of linear alkene in the presence of ZERS Epoxidation of linear alkenes with NaIO4 in the presence of ZERS was investigated under magnetic stirring and ultrasonic irradiation (Tables 6 and 7 ). The results showed by increasing the hydrocarbon chain, the epoxide yield decreases and the reaction times become longer. It seems that catalyst structure is sensitive to chain length and showed a good selectivity toward linear alkenes. As the chain length increases the mobility of alkene reduces, and therefore, accessibility of active site will be difficult and consequently the epoxide yield decreases. Another noteworthy effect of US irradiation was observed in the epoxidation of linear alkenes. The results showed that US waves increases the penetration of linear alkenes toward zeolite cavity and therefore, in shorter times higher epoxide yields were obtained (Table 7). 3.7 Catalyst recovery and reuse in the epoxidation of cyclooctene epoxidation The reusability of ZERS catalyst was tested in the epoxidation of cyclooctene as a model substrate. At the end of each reaction, the catalyst was filtered, washed with acetonitrile and dried at 100°C for 2h. After three consecutive runs under MS and US, the catalytic activity is preserved which showed the ruthenium salophen is still present into nanocavities of zeolite (Table 8 ). This point was proved by comparison of UV–vis and DR FT-IR spectra of fresh and recovered catalyst which suggested that the catalyst is still present within the nanocavities of zeolite (Figs. 7 and 8 ). The decreasing the catalytic activity may be due to the blocking the zeolite canals which prevents the entering the alkenes to the zeolite cavities. The amount of Ru, which was detected in the filtrates in first two runs, was low and after 3rd run no ruthenium was detected in the filtrates. The catalytic behavior of the separated liquid was also tested by addition of fresh cyclooctene and sodium periodate to the filtrates after each run. Execution of the oxidation reaction under the same reaction conditions, as with catalyst, showed that the obtained results were the same as the result of blank experiments. The results obtained by this catalytic system were compared with our previously reported systems using supported ruthenium salophen catalysts [55–57]. The results, which are summarized in Table 9 , show that the nature of the support has a significant effect on the catalytic activity. It seems that in these catalytic systems the support particles size, donating atom and the isolation of catalytic active sites have significant effect on the catalytic activity. For example, the silica supported Ru(salophen)Cl showed a higher catalytic activity due to its smaller particle size in comparison with polystyrene microspheres supported catalyst. In the case of polystyrene-bound Ru(salophen)Cl, the [Ru(salophen)-PSI] bearing imidazole as coordinating ligand is in more reactive than [Ru(salophen)-Amine-PS] in which the coordinating ligands are aromatic amines. This is due to the more electron donating nature of the imidazole in comparison with aromatic amines. In the case of zeolite encapsulated ruthenium salophen, the catalytic active sites are located in the zeolite cavities and are dispersed within the support matrix. Although, the isolation of catalytic active sites increases the catalytic activity, but the penetration of the substrate to the zeolite cavities is more difficult in comparison with the others. However, the encapsulation of metallocomplex in the zeolite cavities leads to a shape and size selectivity in the epoxidation reaction. 4 Conclusion Ru(III)-salophen has been encapsulated within the supercage of NaY zeolite by flexible ligand method. In this case, due to similarity of nanocage size with Ru(III)-salophen dimension, only one complex replace in one supercage, so, due to the isolation of active sites the efficiency of catalyst increased. The encapsulated complex was characterized by UV–vis and FT-IR, DR FT-IR spectroscopic techniques, SEM, TEM, XRD, BET and elemental analysis that confirmed the incorporation of Ru-salophen complex within the supercages of NaY zeolite. This catalyst was used as an efficient and reusable catalyst in the alkene epoxidation with NaIO4 both under magnetic stirring and ultrasonic irradiation conditions. Moreover, ultrasonic irradiation increased the catalytic activity and higher product yields were attained in shorter reaction times. The prepared catalyst was also used for efficient shape-selective epoxidation of linear alkenes. Finally, the catalyst was reused several times. coredata.dc:description: Zeolite-encapsulated ruthenium(III) salophen (ZERS) was prepared by flexible ligand method and characterized by diffuse reflectance FT-IR and UV–vis spectroscopic methods, X-ray diffraction, BET, SEM, TEM and elemental analysis. The amount of Ru-salophen in the zeolite supercages was 0.018mmol/g of encapsulated zeolite. This catalyst was used for efficient and selective epoxidation of different alkenes with NaIO4 under magnetic stirring and ultrasonic irradiation conditions. This catalyst also showed a good shape-selectivity in the epoxidation of linear alkenes. This heterogeneous catalyst was reused several times without significant loss of its catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Host (nanocavity of zeolite Y)-guest (ruthenium(III) salophen complex) nanocomposite materials: An efficient and reusable catalyst for shape-selective epoxidation of linear alkenes with sodium periodate
